hints.content:
Does $\blueD{5 \times (5 \times 2)}=\maroonD{(5 \times 5) \times (5 \times 2)} ?$

$
\begin{align}
\blueD{5 \times (5 \times 2)} &\stackrel{?}{=}  \maroonD{(5 \times 5) \times (5 \times 2)} \\\\
\blueD{5 \times 10} &\neq  \maroonD{25 \times 10}
 \end{align}$

No, $\blueD{5 \times (5 \times 2)}$ is not equivalent to $\maroonD{(5 \times 5) \times (5 \times 2)} $.

Does $\blueD{5 \times (5 \times 2)}=\greenD{(5 \times 5) \times 2}?$

Yes! When multiplying, we can group numbers differently by moving the parentheses and still arrive at the same answer. [[☃ explanation 1]]

This is called the **associative property of multiplication**.

options.showPrompt: Don't believe us? Check this out.

hints.content:
Does $\blueD{5 \times (5 \times 2)}=\purpleC{25 \times 2}?$

$
\begin{align}
\blueD{5 \times (5 \times 2)} &\stackrel{?}{=}  \purpleC{25 \times 2}\\\\
\blueD{(5 \times 5) \times 2} &\stackrel{?}{=}  \purpleC{25 \times 2}&&\text{Associative property of multiplication}\\\\
\blueD{25 \times 2} &=  \purpleC{25 \times 2}
 \end{align}$

Yes, $\blueD{5 \times (5 \times 2)}$ is equivalent to $\purpleC{25 \times 2}$.

The following expressions are equivalent to $\blueD{5 \times (5 \times 2)}$:

* $\greenD{(5 \times 5) \times 2}$

* $\purpleC{25 \times 2}$

question.content:
**Which two expressions are equivalent to ${5 \times (5 \times 2)}$ ?**
